 The Prydain Chronicles by Lloyd Alexander are some of my all-time favorites. All 5 books in the series are good, including the black cauldron and the high king. Alexander also has a 3 book series: Westmark is the first one and The Kestrel is another one I think. I can't remember the third one and I do not have them here. I'm sure you could find them searching Barnes and Nobles or Amazon.com. They are as good as the Prydain chronicles. They are a bit young in terms of reader age for me now but I started reading them in junior high maybe and I continue to re-read them to this day. You never outgrow fantasy.

it's between Grapes of Wrath, For Whom the Bell Tolls, and Timeline.

 
 
 *Shudder* For Whom the Bell Tolls might be the most horrid book ever devised. Junior year English took a lot out of me.
 
 An excerpt from the book, paraphrased to the best of my memory:
 
 
 "Darling."
 "Yes."
 "I love you."
 "Oh."
 "Do you?"
 Yes."
 "You love me."
 "I love you."
 "Let's hide. In this cave. While the war goes on. And die. Alone. In the rain."
 "Wait."
 "What?"
 "How do we die alone? We're together."
 "Oh yeah."
 "I love you."
 "I love you too."
 
 
 My God, I wanted to tear my eyes out. So instead, I just stopped reading it. ;)

So many great books... thus far my personal favorites include:
 
 Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman! - Richard P. Feynman
 Innumeracy: Mathematical Illiteracy And Its Consequences - John Allen Paulos
 Great Ideas In Physics - Alan Lightman
 We The Living - Ayn Rand
 The Demon-Haunted World - Carl Sagan
 A History Of The American People - Paul Johnson
 
 I'm not too big on novels and fictional works, though I'll maintain a bit of a soft spot for the Ayn Rand novels. As well, my bookshelf does include many of the classics mentioned in previous replies: Catcher In The Rye, Crime And Punishment, The Pearl, etc.

 I would recommend Fahrenheit 451 by Ray Bradbury. I read it a few years ago... I think it's one of those books that makes you think, it brought up good points. I would like to read it over again since I was pressed for time to read it and couldn't 'savor' the moment. I would have liked time to think about the things it brought up. I'd also recommend On the Road... although I'm not done with it yet, what I have read I like. You should definitly read Catcher in the Rye... no plot but I found it very amusing. emoticon_rolleyes

Apparently in a list of favourite books Americans rate Ayn Rand second only to the Bible. The Fountainhead and Atlas Shrugged. She has been mentioned here already. In the UK she is unheard and unknown which just goes to show how smarter Americans are than Brits I guess.
 
 Les Miserables by Victor Hugo, for masterly storytelling, mixed with history, philosophy, religion and just about everything else under the sun. Proust Remembrance of things past if you want three thousand pages of amazing cerebral prose, introspection and social observation. Of course concur about Salinger, Hemingway,Lewis,Steinbeck but perhaps Kerouac is best for those in their teens. Ditto Henry Miller.

i just got finished reading cat's cradle by kurt vonnegut... a must read. if not this, go with the classic slaughterhouse-five (by kurt vonnegut). i have yet to read breakfast for champions... i will soon though.
 

 
 God yes, Breakfast of Champions is one of the greatest pieces of fiction ever written. Vonnegut is a genius. If you have time trying reading his collection of short stories in Welcome to the Monkey House or Slapstick . And whoever doesn't understand 1984 's message is doomed. Although, 1984's future predictions are less likely than Brave New World's.

Some of my personal favorites:
 Fahrenheit 451; the way it was written was genius and showed Bradbury in his element. Plus, if you don't see the connections with that world and what we're becoming, then the world is turning to hell
 
 Ender's Game; Not just Ender's game but the sequels as well (it's Xenocide). True to form of human nature in combat. Card is the man of science fiction. Have yet to read Shadow Puppets yet. Looking forward to that.
 
 Animal Farm; Orson Wells made me a fan with this book
 
 Carrie (yes, Stephen King); the man is a writer and I wish that I had the story telling ability that man has.
 
 One of my favorites has to be Catcher in the Rye. Amazing book. It was, in all honesty, about nothing but it told so much. Very few authors can accomplish such a task, let alone in that kind of form. For anyone who hasn't read this, or even heard of it, it is at the top of my list of must reads. Beautiful book, and proof that writing is an art form.
My favorite is Pride and Prejudice. You'd think I was an Victorian teenage schoolgirl or something.

I have so many favs
 but
 Confederacy of the Dunces was great!
what books have made people think/question/grow as a person?

what books have made people think/question/grow as a person?

 If you want something that truly challenges they way you probably think about things, read something by Ayn Rand. Some of her books are very long, so if you just want a taste, you could read Anthem. Either her fiction or non-fiction is provocative since it directly contradicts to the thinking of most authors.

what books have made people think/question/grow as a person?

 
 Honestly, I read The Chocolate War, and I will admit it changed my views as an aspiring. Also, Catcher in the Rye and just the character development of Holden Caufield. Brilliant story telling mixed into the plot to really make you look our society. Then there's Animal Farm, and then...
 well, actually, there are very few books I've read that I don't put down and I am the same. Even with Stephen King that is the case most of the time, and I find something in almost everything. But that's just me.

Originally Posted by college_girl
 what books have made people think/question/grow as a person?

 
 I think that Water Ship Down by Richard Adams and, 2001 Space Odyssey, by Arthur C. Clarke, & Stanley Kubrick were 2 of the best in that way. Also The House Of Stairs by Barbara Vine (I still get chils when I read that one). And anything by Philip K. Dick including Do Androids Dream Of Electric Sheep, A Scaner Darkly, & Dr. Blood Money.
